evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident during the early phase of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_dynamic_und_t1_early scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew remains robust against alternative interpretations or defeaters within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t1_early scope.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The root cause of communication/coordination breakdown among crew fits key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including timing, crew interactions, and situational context within the hist_dynamic_und_t1_early scope.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observable and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t1_early timeframe.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identified procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations within the context of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t1_early data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation aligns with key features identified in pushback operations for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, specifically during the 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t1_early period.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident during the early phase of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_dynamic_und_t1_early scope.

assumptions: Communication via interphone and tug operator interactions reflect crew coordination.
Passing the TRP and hitting the barrier indicates a breakdown in communication/coordination.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident, or if mechanical failure was primary cause.
If procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown better explained the event.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H5 documents communication and coordination actions among crew and tug operators during early pushback, showing communication was active but breakdown occurred as aircraft passed TRP and hit barrier, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing procedural deviation from communication breakdown without further detail on crew interactions and decision-making.

node.statement: The root cause of communication/coordination breakdown among crew fits key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including timing, crew interactions, and situational context within the hist_dynamic_und_t1_early scope.

assumptions: The described crew interactions and timing are representative of communication/coordination breakdown
No other unreported factors (e.g., mechanical failure) influenced the event
defeaters: If evidence showed clear environmental or marking deficiencies causing the event
If hardware or mechanical issues were documented as primary cause

defeaters: If evidence showed environmental markings were inadequate or not visible, or if mechanical control failure caused the deviation, this would change the assessment.

If communication records showed no breakdown or if coordination was clearly effective.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

defeaters: If evidence showed equipment faults or bench checks indicating control malfunction, this would change the conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H5 shows the tug and crew were operational and actively managing pushback, indicating equipment was ready and functional, supporting the claim and favoring procedural deviation over mechanical failure.

assumptions: Communication via interphone and tug operator interactions reflect crew coordination.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident, or if mechanical failure was primary cause.
If procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown better explained the event.

availability.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing procedural deviation from communication breakdown without further detail on crew interactions and decision-making.

assumptions: The absence of mechanical fault evidence implies no mechanical failure occurred.

defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical fault evidence is present; ambiguity remains if unseen mechanical issues contributed.
